Hello!
Our current HubSpot application has the scope “crm.objects.contacts.read”.
We would like to expand the scope with “crm.objects.contacts.write”.

I would like to know if the old installations will have their scope/permissions broken even if they are not reinstalled.
I am aware that they would need to reinstall to gain the new scope/permissions, but do not want older installations to break.
<@U01QVR44MEY>, I was told that you might be able to answer this question for me?
Yes old installation won't break
They just need to reinstall to get the new scope
Great, thank you!
of course

Hello - I'm looking to understand how folks are implementing server to server integrations with HubSpot where no user or browser is available to provide consent at app install time. In an api key scenario, we provide an api key to auth, and then start submitting requests as needed. In the OAuth2 world a user needs to click on links in a browser to provide consent from my understanding. How are folks accomplishing server to server OAuth2 on public apps in a headless environment?
You can do it with private apps
<https://developers.HubSpot.com/docs/api/private-apps>
Yeah, the problem is a private app does not provide webhooks
Basically the same things as api keys but more secure
oh true true
Is that something you guys definitely need?

Well, in short, that's our current ideal direction. The other option, to continually poll is much less appealing. It seems like HubSpot has a gap in their offerings related to webhooks in headless server to server integrations...
Yes very true, unless of course you can get a user to do the oauth process just once during the initial setup
Yeah, I've thought of just installing a terminal based browser to see if that can at least work, but that's less than ideal and seems pretty fragile imo
Yes for sure fragile, what do you think about sending the users a link to do the auth process?
That could work, can you expand on that idea?
I would first need to know a little bit about what you're trying to do
Basically you would send the user of your app a link in an email to go through the auth flow for your app
On the backend once the user auths your server can kick off the sync
ah, yea let me ponder that - here I'm thinking the install process has to be initiated from the server where the data will flow from/to but yea the auth flow could come from somewhere else...
Yeah the more I think of it, that's the obvious answer, thanks for helping me get there!
Solved this using contact properties, and copying the values over to the deal properties
